title: How is ENIAC different than the modern computer? - Quora

response.answer_text: Eniac is a very different beast compared to today’s computers. For starters , a modern microprocessor is litterally hundreds of millions times faster than ENIAC . With modern manufacturing , a transistor-based re-creation of ENIAC could fit on a single grain of sand. That’s how far we’ve come. Modern microprocessors use transistors , tiny electric “switches” . This has allowed to drastically reduce to their size and ocst , and increase their power. In 50 years , we’ve made transistors that were over 10 µm wide all the way to modern transistors measuring only a couple dozen nm wide.ENIAC uses vacuum tubes and a complement of various discrete electric components (capacitors , resistors etc ). These were power hungry and unreliable . Eniac used 170Kw . A modern PC uses a couple hundred watts at most.Servers and mainframes can use that much though , but we’re talking much more powerful machines. Size has also been drastically reduced , with ENIAC taking up an entire room. Those were the obvious differences. Aside from that , ENIAC wasn’t truly general purpose machine . It was primarily made to calculate ballistic trajectories. That’s relatively simple math, and can be done using integers or even fixed point math . No floating point math here. It wasn’t made to do much else ( though it did help with nuclear weapons development ). It had no storage to speak of , programs were instead entered through a plug board . This process was laborious . Eniac was a decimal computer , not binary like today’s machine. Eniac didn’t even work off the same computing models of today’s machines. While ENIAC did work off an ancestor of a von-neumann architecture , it was not a stored-program computer (at least not at first) was fundamentally very different from today’s modified-Harvard architecture.
